item.title: Why cancer cells waste so much energy
item.description: MIT biologists have found a possible explanation for the Warburg effect, first seen in cancer cells in the 1920s. They found cancer cells use fermentation, an inefficient metabolic pathway, because it helps them to generate large quantities of a molecule called NAD+, which they need to synthesize DNA and other important molecules.
item.author: (Anne Trafton | MIT News Office)

item.title: The Unsettling Truth About the ‘Mostly Harmless’ Hiker
item.description: His emaciated body was discovered in a tent, just a few miles from a major Florida highway. His identity—and troubled past—were discovered by the internet.

item.title: Food on the table while giving away code
item.description: I founded the curl project early 1998 but had already then been working on the code since November 1996. The source code was always open, free and available to the world. The term “open source” actually wasn’t even coined until early 1998, just weeks before curl was born.

item.title: HuffPost is now a part of Verizon Media
item.description: HuffPost is part of Verizon Media. We and our partners will store and/or access information on your device through the use of cookies and similar technologies, to display personalised ads and content, for ad and content measurement, audience insights and product development.

item.title: Uganda's January 13, 2021 Internet Shut Down
item.description: Two days ago, through its communications regulator, Uganda's government ordered the "Suspension Of The Operation Of Internet Gateways" hours before the country's general election. This action was confirmed by several users and journalists who got access to the letter sent to Internet providers.
item.author: (Celso Martinho)

item.title: The perils of the accidental C++ conversion constructor | The Old New Thing
item.description: Consider this class: class Buffer { public: Buffer(size_t capacity); Buffer(std::initializer_list<int> values); }; You can create an uninitialized buffer with a particular capacity, or you can create an initialized buffer. The one-parameter constructor also serves as a conversion constructor, resulting in the following: Buffer buffer(24);
item.author: (Raymond Chen Follow)

item.title: KEMTLS: Post-quantum TLS without signatures
item.description: The TLS 1.3 protocol has been around for quite some time, but it will be broken once quantum computers arrive. What can we do? In this blog post, we will examine a technique for achieving full post-quantum security for TLS 1.3 in the face of quantum computers: KEMTLS.
item.author: (Sofía Celi)

item.title: Taking the new Chromium WebView2 Control for a Spin in .NET - Part 1
item.description: This is Part 1 of a two part article that gives an overview of the new WebView2 Web browser control that is based on Edge Chromium. In Part 1 I look at the basics of what's needed to run the control using the WebView runtime, and how to get the control embedded and configured to use for basic HTML tasks. In Part 2 I look at interaction between the .NET application and WebBrowser and Javascript.
item.author: (https://facebook.com/rickstrahl)

item.title: Exploring Event Modeling with Adam Dymitruk | Hanselminutes with Scott Hanselman
item.description: Event Modeling was coined by Adam Dymitruk by building on long-running process specifications that Greg Young used in CQRS/ES systems. Scott sits down with Adam to understand this process and how it make make your systems - and your life making those systems - easier to write, understand, and maintain.
